user.biography: Home to Bruichladdich, Port Charlotte and Octomore Islay single malts. We’re proud to be the first Scotch whisky distillery to be B Corp certified.

node.text:
Head Distiller Adam Hannett and Production Director Allan Logan recorded live on Bruichladdich Day, tasting our festival bottle and our house whisky side by side. 

If it’s making your mouth water, you can enter our ballot for the Laddie Origins til 12:00 noon BST tomorrow. And help yourself to a Classic in the meantime. See link in bio.

#timetravellers #feisile

node.text:
Live from outside distillery gates, Frazer provides an update on what’s been and what’s still to come.

Link in our bio to join in the fun over the next 90 minutes!

node.text:
Live cocktail session with Ewald @talkin_laddie
 
Our man in Germany, Switzerland and Austria created a drink inspired by the famous Foo Fighters song. It pretends to be a heavy winter drink but is actually a crisp summer refreshment with a deep red colour.

Here is the recipe:

5 cl Classic Laddie infused with lemon thyme and black mallow
3 cl homemade smoky Blueberry syrup
1 cl Tawny Port
1 bar spoon Balsamic Vinegar
Ginger Ale
Decoration: Orange peel and lemon thyme

You will find more info about how to prep the ingredients in the download pack for the Time Travellers festival. Register for the festival via link in bio.

node.text:
Talking B Corp over a few drinks. 
Community, Environment, Governance, Workers and Customers - what does it mean to be measuring our impacts in these areas? And how tasty is a tea / tisane + whisky combo!?

Recipes:

🌱 Peppermint Julep 
50ml Classic Laddie
1 Teapigs Peppermint tea temple
50ml boiled water
2 tsp brown sugar
ice
shaker
fresh mint for garnish

Brew your peppermint tea for 5-10 minutes in 50ml of freshly boiled water – the longer you brew, the mintier the final flavour.
Add sugar while it’s still hot, then allow it to cool.
Add whisky and shake with ice.
Strain into an old fashioned glass over crushed ice and garnish with fresh mint.

🌻 Chamomile Sours 
50ml Classic Laddie
1 Teapigs Chamomile tea temple
50ml boiled water
30g sugar
30ml lemon juice
30ml aquafaba or 1 egg white

Brew your chamomile tea for 5 – 10 mins in 50ml freshly boiled water.
Add sugar while it’s still hot, then allow it to cool.
Add to shaker with the other ingredients and shake for 1min without ice. Then add ice and shake again until cool.
Strain into old fashioned glass.

node.text:
Adam and Frazer tasting our newly released Islay barley vintage against the previous year’s. 

Apologies for the connectivity issues, they don’t seem to be something we can resolve in-house. But we will repost this chat with the missing pieces in the next few days. Slainte!

node.text:
For anyone who missed Nick's episodic Sunday show matching malts and music, here's the full collection. 

Featuring 10 Bruichladdich Islay Barley, Organic, PC10, PC MRC 01, Octomore 10.1, 10.3, 10.4, Black Art 6, Bere Barley 2010 & Classic Laddie paired with eclectic, thought-provoking, (fairly obscure) (usually Belgian) records... 

Knock yourselves out over the holidays :) 

@nick_baeyens fanclub starts here.

node.text:
This week we excitedly saw the rye from @coullfarmislay go through our mash tun, so here are some musings with farmer Andrew Jones on their 2020 barley harvest.

Andrew, his father Donald and fiancée Sophie brought in the barley this September, “The best harvest weather we’ve had since growing for Bruichladdich”. Donald was growing barley on the farm for over 30 years before Bruichladdich barley was even a thought: “He’s the man that knows the farm, he knows if a field has barley in it it will need X ,Y and Z. He’s keeps and eye from the moment the combines are going to the end, he keeps me right!’. 
🌾
Andrew says 2018 harvest was a record year and while 2019 tonnage was down a little, 2020 was up again. The last load into the shed was brought in by Donald in his ATV trailer, a real family effort.

Thank you, thank you, thank you to all our barley growers across the country in this unexpected year. Farming never rests.
🌾
Look out for the full interview audio with Andrew next week.
🚜
Thanks to @sophiemacgillxo and @jonesy871 for sharing your footage.

#islaybarley #isleofislay #islaywhisky

node.text:
Seeing out the bank holiday weekend with a Port Charlotte cask exploration.
-
Which of the cask explorations is your favourite? Fine French wine, a Sicilian DOC, Eau de vie, Sherry…  The somewhat cryptic initials in the series are because we’re not legally allowed to tell you the exact chateaux where we source our wood.
-
The good news is there are plenty more exceptional casks biding their time in our warehouses where they came from! Great flavour combinations with our floral, heavily-peated Islay single malt, turning it slowly autumnal pink, or ruby, adding soft peach, dried fruit, muscularity… 
-
Browse the full range of currently available Port Charlotte whiskies via link in bio. And watch this space; next edition is on the horizon 
-
#dramfortheweekend #whisky #islaywhisky #singlemalt #scotch #cask #casks #portcharlotte

node.text:
That’s Donald McCormick of Blackrock passing to and fro with the first of the #islaybarley harvest this afternoon.
-
The wee birdies straight in to pick up the spares! He’s headed down to get the grain weighed and dried for storing at Octofad Farm in the Rhinns.
-
The warm weather of the last few days is set to continue for another week so we expect the road in front of the distillery to be rumbling with trailers from now on. Brilliant to have so much of our barley grown within the circumference of the island now, after starting from scratch with one farmer in 2004.
-
#progress #provenance #farming #harvest #harvesthome #maltingbarley #islaywhisky #scotch #whiskystartsinthefield

•••

Venison meatballs with wild herbs at the Wilderness Festival recently. Traceable meat, fire cooking, and a little bit of rock and roll… Chef Nick Weston proved you can live in a treehouse without giving up the finer things in life, in fact it brings you closer to them. If you like his style as much as we do, check out the Hunter Gather Cook cookbook.

Sometimes it’s simply not possible to choose a single #dramfortheweekend so we’ll leave this one up to you. Which of the Octomore 11s would choose? 

Octomore 11.1: Malted to 139.6ppm, matured in Ex-American Oak

Octomore 11.2: Malted to 139.6ppm, matured in Ex-Pauillac-Bourbon-St. Julien

Octomore 11.3: Single Farm, Single Vintage Octomore Farm Grown Islay Barley, Malted to 194ppm

Octomore Ten Year Old: Malted to 208ppm, 10 Years Old, matured in Virgin Oak

Have a great weekend all. 🥃

node.text:
Last week, we released two new barley vintages. In our final introductory shoutout to these vintage releases, we’re spotlighting the Port Charlotte Islay Barley 2013 and the Bruichladdich Bere Barley 2011.

First up the Port Charlotte Islay Barley 2013: This eight-year-old single malt has matured in ex-American and ex-wine casks hailing from the Pessac Léognan region of France. According to our head distiller, the first sip of this heavily peated spirit is a wondrous thing; Notes of redberry fruits, toasted oak with hints of coffee and chocolate combines with the distinctive sophisticated smoky character of the Port Charlotte malt.

Bruichladdich Bere Barley 2011: There is something unique about Bere spirit with its depth of flavour magnifying our unpeated whisky’s complexity. Distilled in 2011 and aged in first fill American oak barrels, this dram is held together by a succulent apricot jam note that highlights the unrivalled unctuous texture and barley-sugar sweetness of this six-row, ancient grain.

node.text:
Our Port Charlotte heavily peated single malts are an embodiment of everything an Islay whisky could and should be. Not only are they conceived, distilled, matured and bottled on the island, the barley harvest for this 2013 vintage was also grown on our home shores in 2012 by seven of our Islay farming partners. 

Delving into the archives to remind ourselves of the foundations for this new vintage of Port Charlotte Islay Barley 2013, we revisit an article exploring some of our thoughts on what constitutes an 'Islay' single malt. Link in bio - What is an Islay single malt?

📸 Behind the lens @ianson - taken on the new footpath connecting Bruichladdich and Port Charlotte villages - a project supported by our distillery in order to give back to the community. 

#hereallyear #islaysinglemalt #peatedmalt #peatedsinglemalt #weareislay

node.text:
Our Bere barley releases over the years have proven that not all barley is created equal, and this year’s vintage is no different. Besides the great flavour or Bere barley single malt whisky, you are holding something fascinating, useful and still rather enigmatic in your glass. 

Bere is an adaptable grain, and despite its low yield which has deemed it less popular among farmers it can grow in harsh climates and withstand challenging growing conditions.

Dr Peter Martin, Director of the Agronomy Institute at the University of the Highlands and Islands along with John Wishart and the Barony Mill have played a crucial role in the resurrection and research of of this ancient grain. 

To read more about their research or to shop our newest Bere barley vintage click the link in our bio.

node.text:
Introducing two new barley vintages. 🥃
 
Barley exploration has always been our mission since our resurrection in 2001. We’ve been building a different way of sourcing our all important ingredient outside of the traditional means. By nurturing relationships with farmers, maltsters, agronomists, and barley breeders, we’ve encouraged these people to work with us to reconnect the liquid in the glass back to the raw ingredient and the people who gave them life.
 
The two vintages we release today are a testament to the stamina and longevity of our first barley projects and those who have persevered with us on our mission to explore new realms of flavour and provenance in single malt whisky.
 
Introducing Bruichladdich Bere Barley 2011 and Port Charlotte Islay Barley 2013… Two vintages; one unpeated made from an ancient grain grown in Orkney, and one heavily peated single malt distilled from island grown barley across seven local farms.

Link in bio for more details.

node.text:
We’re back!

After the annual two week shut down for essential maintenance, we’re back mashing Bruichladdich Islay Barley. 

By Wednesday afternoon the stills will be going and it’ll be business as usual at the distillery. 

Keep your eyes peeled for some new barley vintages this week. It’s not too late to join our mailing list to stay up to date. Link in bio 🥃
